newsitem.title: BELGIUM: BELGIAN BONDS SUFFER FROM EXHAUSTION, WATCH U.S.
newsitem.headline: BELGIAN BONDS SUFFER FROM EXHAUSTION, WATCH U.S.

text.p: Belgian linear bonds headed languidly lower in morning trading on Wednesday, tracking German Bunds and with attention focused on a flush of forthcoming figures from the United States.
"This is a tired and offered market," one trader said, noting pressure on short maturity paper and buying of long paper producing a yield curve flattening move.
"Nothing is doing well on the short end. This market is due for a larger correction downwards," he added.
"There are very important U.S. figures today and Thursday. They will set the tone for the rest of the week," he said.
U.S. July retail sales and producer prices are due this afternoon. They are seen rising 0.7 percent and 0.1 percent respectively.
On Thursday July consumer prices and June industrial production figures feature among a host of other data.
Traders said the prospect of these figures was keeping the Belgian bond market relatively quiet on Wednesday, as was the mild upward pressure on money market rates and currency worries.
At 0900 GMT the yield of the benchmark 10 year OLO was 5.78 percent against Tuesday's closing 5.74 percent. The spread over Bunds was an unchanged nine basis points.
The front month futures contract was 29 basis points off at 121.00.
The one-week repo rate was 3.31/36 percent against late Tuesday's 3.28/31, and the mark/franc was 20.6505/15 against 20.6465/95.
